{{short description|Undead beings}}
[[File:Angus McBride - Wraith.jpg|thumb|[[Angus McBride]] - ''Wraith'']]

'''Wraiths''' was a name for people having been transformed into [[undead]] beings.<ref name=FRI11>{{FR|I11}}</ref> The realm of the wraiths was called the [[Unseen|Wraith-world]].<ref name=FRII1/>

==History==

In the [[Elder Days]], the wraith of [[Gorlim]] appeared in a dream of [[Beren]].<ref>{{S|19}}</ref>

In the [[Second Age]], the [[Men]] of the [[White Mountains]] broke their oath to [[Isildur]]. This crime combined by Isildur's curse turned the [[Oathbreakers]] into shades who haunted the mountains<ref>{{RK|V3}}</ref> until the [[Third Age]]. [[Aragorn]] II, in the capacity of the [[Heir of Isildur]], released the Oathbreakers from their curse in return for their aid at [[Pelargir]].<ref>{{RK|Debate}}</ref>

In the Third Age, it was rumoured that the wraith of [[Helm|Helm Hammerhand]] haunted the enemies of [[Rohan]], killing those who felt fear.<ref>{{App|A2}}</ref>

The most famous of the wraiths were the [[Nazgûl|Ringwraiths]], [[Men]] ensnared by [[Sauron]]'s [[Nine Rings]].<ref name=LotR>[[J.R.R. Tolkien]], ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'', ''passim''</ref> Some of the victims of the Ringwraiths, too, could be transformed into wraiths, albeit lesser and under their command (although there are no records of such a being).<ref name=FRII1>{{FR|II1}}</ref> This nearly happened to [[Frodo Baggins]], after having been stabbed by the [[Morgul-knife]] of the [[Witch-king]].<ref name=FRI11/>

==Etymology==
The [[Black Speech]]/[[Sindarin]] word ''[[gûl]]'' was translated as "wraith(s)" in the [[Red Book of Westmarch]].<ref name=LotR/><ref>{{PE|17}}, p. 11</ref><ref>[[Helge Fauskanger]], "[http://folk.uib.no/hnohf/orkish.htm Orkish and the Black Speech: Base Language for Base Purposes]" at [http://www.uib.no/People/hnohf/ Ardalambion] (accessed 27 December 2010)</ref>

==Other versions of the legendarium==
In a draft for ''[[The Lord of the Rings Appendices]]'', the [[Paths of the Dead]] were said to have been guarded by the "''fell wraiths of the [[Oathbreakers|Forgotten Men]]''".<ref>{{PM|Aii}}, p. 267</ref>

In another draft it is said that the [[Rings of Power]] transformed their bearers into wraiths, thus creating ''elf-'', ''goblin-'', ''men-'', or ''dwarf-wraiths''.<ref>{{RS|Gollum}}, p. 78</ref>

==Inspiration==
''Wraith'' is a Scottish word meaning "ghost" (of uncertain origin; possibly from Gaelic, Irish ''arrach''  "specter, apparition").<ref>Douglas Harper, "[http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=wraith wraith]" at [http://www.etymonline.com Online Etymology Dictionary] (accessed 26 December 2010)</ref><ref>{{HM|RW}}, p. 223</ref>

==Portrayal in adaptations==
'''1982-97: ''[[Middle-earth Role Playing]]'':'''
:The wraith '''Gaurithoth''', an undead Númenórean lieutenant, serves the Witch-king and haunts a burial mound near the Blue Mountains.<ref>{{ICE|8007}}, pp. 38-39</ref>

'''2001: ''[[Middle-earth Strategy Battle Game]]'':'''
:The '''[[Castellans of Dol Guldur]]''' are wraiths in the service of [[Sauron]]. Nameless and with no will of their own, the Castellans are but one facet of that cursed tower’s sleepless malice. Formless, save for the armour that binds them, they stalk the paths about [[Dol Guldur]], slaying those they find. Each fell to Sauron’s service in a different way; some sought to learn from him as an apprentice does from a master, and others are the eternal remnants of one who has died in agony in Sauron’s dungeons. However they came into the Dark Lord’s service, they are all now bound to his curse and serve him absolutely.

'''2002-5: ''[[The Lord of the Rings Roleplaying Game]]'':'''
: Wraiths are the most common of the three type of [[ghosts]] (the other being [[phantoms]] and [[wights]]). The wraith is without a physical, tangible form, and consists only of the soul of a person wishing to fulfil an evil goal after his or her death.<ref>{{D|Fell}}, pp. 25-27</ref>

'''2007: ''[[The Lord of the Rings Online]]'':'''
: Wraiths refers to the category of Unseen beings that includes the [[Nazgûl]] and victims of [[Morgul-knife|Morgul blades]]. The cursed, lingering spirits of Men such as the [[Oathbreakers|Dead Men of Dunharrow]] are called Shades and categorized as The Dead. Wraiths appeared as leaders of the Enemy and elite forces in many areas. The most commonly encountered wraiths were the red-robed Cargûl. One of the game's main antagonists, [[Mordirith]], was a wraith who is the Steward of [[Angmar]].
